The loan will help her to have a larger stock of animals, with the end of increasing her business of the same and to satisfy the needs of her customers, which will generate a higher income for her, with which she will improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of pigs, ducks, hens, and turkeys, among other animals, to increase her business.

loans.name: Oyugi

texts.en:
Oyugi is a smallholder farmer from the village of Keera in the Nyamira area of Kenya. When you ask, he’ll tell you his most valuable asset is his farm. But it wasn’t always this way. For a long time, Oyugi’s farm couldn’t even sustain his family. In 2013, he heard about Juhudi Kilimo, a micro-finance institution that serves smallholder farmers. And from that day, life has never been the same. Oyugi is happily married and, together with his beautiful wife, he is blessed with five lovely children. For the past 30 years, he has been practicing mixed farming and his primary sources of income have been milk, eggs and a variety of food crops. He sells milk and farm produce to his neighbors and to the local market. However, he has been facing one big problem and that is the timely delivery of his products to the market. 

He is seeking a loan to buy a motorbike that would solve his transportation problem. Keera is located in a very remote area that has a poor road network and the terrain is very bad. The only mode of transport is a motorbike. This loan will be of great help because it will allow Oyugi to transport his farm products to the market and deliver them in a timely manner. Milk and vegetables are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market in order to fetch high prices. Through the loan, Oyugi will not be worried because he will always be able to deliver the products on time and gain more profits. This motorbike will be a reliable source of quick transportation for both long and short distances. Through the motorbike, Oyugi's life is going to change and his standard of living is going to improve.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 57 years old and married with five children. With two of her children in school, she works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, home care products and other groceries.

Rosita has been in this business for 10 years now. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like canned goods, home care products and other groceries

loans.name: Ameer

texts.en: Ameer is a 35-year-old woman. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother of 4 children. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. For the past many days his rickshaw has not been working properly; because of this her husband is unable to generate any amount of income. He wants to repair it as soon as possible. However due to lack of money he finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairing the rickshaw. Therefore Ameer has requested a loan from Kiva partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing his rickshaw. This will help him to continue his business. Ameer is so thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to repair her husband's rickshaw

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en: Scovia is twenty-nine years old, married with two children, and living in Kasese, Uganda. For five years she has been running a retail shop of general merchandise. She began the business to support her family in addition to the income that her husband fetches. Scovia is a hard-working woman with the dream of growing her business into a big general store that will in turn increase her profits. However, she is faced with the challenge of limited capital and general price fluctuation. She intends to use the loan to buy sugar, soap, cooking oil and other general merchandise for selling.

loans.use: to buy sugar, soap, cooking oil and other general merchandise for selling.

loans.name: Balanouwé

texts.fr: Agée de 56 ans, Balanouwé est une femme qui vit à Agoè avec six  personnes à sa charge.  Pour avoir son revenu, Balanouwé prépare et vend de la boisson locale communément appelée Tchoukoutchou faite à base du mil. Pour répondre efficacement aux besoins, Balanouwé s’approvisionne quatre fois par mois au marché. Balanouwé demande ce crédit pour commander des sacs de mil afin de réaliser encore plus de revenus pour soutenir  les charges quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Balanouwé, age 56, is a woman who lives in Agoè and supports six people. To make a living, she sells a local beverage called Tchoukoutchou that she prepares using millet. To meet customer demand, she buys ingredients at the market four times per month.

Balanouwé is seeking this loan to order sacks of millet. This will help her to bolster her sales and better support her family’s daily needs.

loans.use: to buy a few sacks of millet.

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “NUEVA VICTORIA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Chinchero, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia Juana se dedica al negocio de artesania, la socia vende  tejidos, chompas, mantas y telares, la socia vende diferentes tejidos, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 8 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de tejidos y telares. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar tejidos, chompas y telares.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Juana belongs to the "Nueva Victoria" communal bank, which is located in the district of Chinchero, in the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco.

Juana works as an artesan, selling material, sweaters, blankets and looms. She sells all different materials and she works from 8:00 am until 7:00 pm. She has been doing this work for eight years and things are going well for her. Her dream is to expand the material and loom selling business.

She is requesting the loan to buy material, sweaters and looms. She is happy for the loan and she promises to comply with her repayment schedule.

loans.use: to buy material, sweaters and looms.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Amadou est celui qui tient le raccord qui jette l’eau.
Amadou est un Malien âgé de 43 ans ; il est marié et père de 3 enfants dont deux (2) scolarisés .Ces enfants sont âgés de 8 à 15 ans et il vit dans un milieu rural du Mali.
Depuis 15 ans il fait le maraichage. Il avait le problème de fond pour bien mener son activité.
C’est pour cela qu’il a fait recourt à l’IMF avec son groupe.
Le fond qu’il reçoit du RMCR est investi dans son activité de maraichage. Dans son jardin on y trouve des poivrons, des tomates, des concombres, des choux, des oignons, des piments et des aubergines. Il achète des semences de légumes dans le marché local, les cultive  et ensuite il revend la production dans les marchés locaux en vue de réaliser un profit. Le bénéfice qu’il gagne lui permet d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille à savoir l’éducation, la santé, l’habillement, la nourriture, des enfants et de sa femme. Son bénéfice prévisionnel mensuellement au moment de la cueillette est de 100 000FCFA par mois.
texts.en:
Amadou, age 43, is married man from Mali with three children ages 8 to 15, two of them in school. He lives in a rural area of Mali. He is the member holding the hose in the group photo. 

Amadou has been a market gardener for 15 years. In his garden, he grows bell peppers, tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, onions, hot peppers and eggplant. 

Lacking capital to run his activity successfully, he and the other group members turned to the RMCR microfinance organization. The funds obtained from the MFI are invested in his activity. Amadou buys vegetable seeds at the local market and sells his crops at nearby markets to earn a profit that helps him to improve his family’s living conditions in terms of education, clothing, healthcare and food. 

At harvest time, he expects to earn a profit of 100,000FCFA per month.

loans.use: to buy seeds for his market gardening activity.

loans.name: Martha Rocio

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como 4 esquinas en la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días las socias  del Grupo De Crédito Nueva Esperanza, Portoviejo es una ciudad rodeada de vegetación y un hermoso rio que baña los campos los mismos que son propicios para los cultivos.
En este lugar vive la señora Martha, tiene 30 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 14, 12 y 7 años, todos estudian en colegio y el menor en escuela. El marido es albañil. 
Doña Martha con la intención de ganar algo por su cuenta y con esto poder salir adelante junto a su familia  se dedica al comercio, vende zapatos  por catalogo  y varios artículos para el hogar como cortinas, sabanas, etc. Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y también en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes más conocidos, ella deja a crédito y va cobrando cada 8 días. Lleva más de 15  años que se dedica al comercio y es lo que le encanta hacer
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar zapatos de todo tipo. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos financia mejor su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus pequeños.
texts.en:
The members of the Nueva Esperanza loan group meet twice a month in the area known as the 4 Esquinas (Four Corners) in the town of Portoviejo. The town is surrounded by vegetation and a beautiful river, the water from which makes the surrounding fields suitable for agriculture.
30-year old Sra. Martha lives here with her husband and three children aged 14, 12, and 7. All attend school. Her husband works in construction.

So she would have her own income and be able to help her family get ahead, Martha runs a business selling shoes from a catalogue, as well as various household items such as curtains, sheets etc. She goes door to door with the catalogue, and also her best-known customers come to her house. She sells on credit and collects money every 8 days. Martha has had her business for more than 15 years, and she loves doing it.

She plans to use this loan to buy all kinds of shoes. She has been with this loan group since the beginning and likes it because the loan money helps her improve the business. Her dream is to give the best she can to her children.

loans.use: buy shoes

loans.name: Gs Amor Y Paz Group

texts.es:
La Lidia   es una mujer emprendedora y dedicada al negocio, el cual es la venta de abarrotería en general actividad que realiza desde hace 4 años , ella vende todos los días de la semana y las ventas las realiza desde su casa de habitación, ella vende pollo, refrescos, harina, manteca, azúcar, pan, churros, sardinas, espaguetis, los clientes principales son personas que habitan en la zona donde ella vive, este local está ubicado en un punto estratégico a orilla de la pavimentada donde transitan personas en grandes cantidades.
Lidia solicita el préstamo para la compra de pollo, refrescos, harina, manteca, azúcar, pan, churros, sardinas, espaguetis para poder surtir la pulpería porque se aproxima la semana santa y ella manifiesta que en tiempos de celebridades, las ventas aumentan mucho mas.
Lidia sueña con poder expandir su negocio  y con las ganancias que obtenga del negocio sus hijos puedan seguir estudiando, ella solicita el préstamo de forma grupal con las siguientes personas.
Marilú se dedica a la venta de zapatos y ropa americana desde hace 6 años.
Anna se dedica a la venta de zapatos, carteras, ropa americana desde hace 4 años, todos ellos solicitan el préstamo porque no cuentan con el capital suficiente para atender en sus negocios. 


 Marzo 2015
texts.en:
Sra. Lidia is an enterprising woman who is dedicated to her business selling a variety of groceries. She’s had her business for four years. The store is open every day, and Lidia runs it from her house. She sells chicken, soft drinks, flour, butter, sugar, bread, doughnuts, sardines, and spaghetti. Her main customers are from the area where she lives; her home is in a good position on the paved road used by lots of people.

Lidia is seeking a loan to buy stock for her store such as chicken, soft drinks, flour, butter, sugar, bread, doughnuts, sardines, and spaghetti. Holy Week is approaching, and she knows that sales increase a lot during holiday times.

Marilú has sold shoes, purses, and American clothing for six years.

Anna has sold shoes, purses, and American clothing for four years.

All of the women are seeking loans because they don’t have enough capital to buy stock their businesses.

March 2015

loans.use: buy chicken, soft drinks, flour, butter, sugar, bread, doughnuts, sardines, and spaghetti for her grocery store

loans.name: Ketty Beatriz

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como 4 esquinas en la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días las socias  del Grupo De Crédito Nueva Esperanza, Portoviejo es una ciudad rodeada de vegetación y un hermoso rio que baña los campos los mismos que son propicios para los cultivos.
En este lugar vive la señora Ketty, tiene 41 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cinco hijos de 17, 16, 15 y 10 años  de edad, una de sus hijos falleció hace años,  todos estudian en colegio y el menor es especial y estudia en escuela. El marido trabaja ocasionalmente. 
Doña Ketty al ver que su marido no gana mucho y que en ocasiones no tiene trabajo hace mas de 4  años surtió en su casa una pequeña tienda de víveres, allí empezó a vender solo  productos, como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, entre otros víveres primarios, ya después con la ayuda de los créditos ella ha ido aumentando la variedad de productos, ahora también vende artículos de bazar y papelería, con esto ha ganado más clientela con lo cual le quedan mejores ingresos que ella los invierte para ir mejorando su negocio y para las cosas necesarias en su hogar y crianza de sus hijos.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, útiles escolares y cosas de bazar. Esta desde el inicio en el Grupo Crédito y le gusta porque con los  créditos mejora su negocio. Sus metas son seguir aumentando su tienda cada día más.
texts.en:
The members of 'Nueva Esperanza' Communal Bank meet every fortnight in a neighbourhood known as 4 corners in the city of Portoviejo. It is a city surrounded by greenery and a beautiful river that bathes the fertile fields.

Here is where Ketty lives. She is 41 years old and in a common-law marriage from which she has 5 children. They are 17, 16, 15 and 10 years old (one of them died years ago), they all study in high school except the youngest who goes to elementary school.

Her husband only works occasionally. Seeing that he does not make much and is sometimes unemployed, Ketty decided to set up a small grocery store in her house more than 4 years ago.

There, she began selling products such as rice, sugar, oil and detergent among other convenience store items. Then, thanks to previous loans, she increased the range of products and now she also sells household products and stationary.

This way she has increased her customer base and therefore she makes more profits, which she reinvests in her business or uses to buy what her family needs.

She will use this loan to stock her store, she will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, school supplies and household products.

She has been part of the Communal Bank from the beginning and she likes it because the loans allow her to improve her business. Her goal is to keep expanding her store more and more.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergent, school supplies and household products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stocks of fruit.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en: Johnson is age 45 and married with six children, and all of them attend school in Hoima, Uganda. He started his business of dealing in a retail shop in order to generate income to support his family. He also gets additional income from growing crops. He hopes to educate his children, as well as develop his business. He will use the credit facility to buy more stock to sell like salt, sugar, and plastics.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell like salt, sugar, and plastics.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of snacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy candy, beverages, snacks, bread, etc. She will offer new products in her store that are liked by her customers.

loans.name: Rasoolan

texts.en:
Rasoolan is 45 years old and a married woman. She is running a business selling milk with her husband. She has buffaloes and cows for milk production. Her husband sells the milk in nearby areas.  Rasoolan ’s job is to look after the buffaloes and collect the milk from them. Together, both husband and wife are supporting their family. However, they need to earn more income for their everyday expenditures. 

Therefore, Rasoolan has requested for 60,000 PKR to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers, providing a better standard of living for her family members.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers, providing a better standard of living for her family members.

loans.name: Efat

texts.en:
Efat, 44 years old, is a very enthusiastic person who has been successfully running a small general store with her husband (also shown in the photo). 

She offers a variety of daily use products and has a good client base. In order to avoid shortages, Efat  needs to have various goods in stock to efficiently meet customer demand. 

Efat has requested a loan of PKR 40,000  to buy additional grocery items, including oil, milk, sugar, and juices to consistently meet the increasing demand at her store and to make better earnings.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items, including oil, milk, sugar, and juices.

loans.name: Nazeeran

texts.en:
Nazeeran is a 42-year-old married woman with three children. She is very skilled in the art of making parandas (hair accessories) and has been using her skill for many years to earn a living. Nazeeran can make beautiful designs with her hands and her skill is known throughout the town. 

Nazeeran is requesting a 60,000 PKR loan to purchase more beads, threads, and frames to meet customer orders on time to earn good profits. Her loan will help move her closer to her dream of providing a quality education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase beads, threads, and frames to make hair accessories

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy cattle to fatten and resell.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida is 42 years old, and a married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing stock of goods from the market as he has maintained many contacts in years. She is a mother of five children and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing, and health. 

She wants to grow her business, so she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy packs of salts, biscuits, rice, spices and juices to handle increasing demands of her customers efficiently, and to boost her earnings for expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits, rice, spices and juices to handle increasing demands of her customers efficiently.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so as to increase his milk supply for more income.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a married man. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail business where he sells furniture. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in a busy area. 

He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy materials and machinery for making furniture. His business goal is to expand within five years. He hopes that in the future he will have improved living standards. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy materials and machinery for making furniture.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a single woman with one child. She describes herself to be honest.

Susan operates a retail business where she sells sorghum, beans and millet. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be changes in weather. She will use the KES 10,000 loan to buy more stock of cereals.

She hopes that in the future, she will be financially independent.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cereals.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman who has three children with ages ranging from 17 years to 25 years. She describes herself to be outgoing. She operates a restaurant. She has been involved in this business for 15 years. Her business is located in a favorable location and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy stock of ingredients for preparing food. Her business goal is to open a medium sized hotel within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy stock of ingredients for preparing food.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a married man and he has three children. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a retail business where he sells clothes. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in an area favorable for the business, and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

He will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. His business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. This is his fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en:
Veronicah is a married woman. She has four children. She describes herself to be honest. 

She operates a farm where she grows coffee. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in a strategic place and her primary customers are large scale. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient working capital. 

She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of farm inputs. 

This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of farm inputs

loans.name: Rosa Elizabeth

texts.es:
Rosa, con el préstamo anterior ha tenido la oportunidad de fortalecer la tienda y establecer mejor la pupusería, sus ingresos son más estables y los ha utilizado para hacer mejoras en su vivienda y dar un mejor estilo de vida a su familia.
Con el propósito de seguir creciendo con su negocio se decidió por un nuevo préstamo para invertir en aceite, pan huevos, detergentes, arroz, pastas, etc., de esa manera sus clientes siempre encontraran el producto que necesitan.
texts.en:
With the previous loan, Rosa has had the opportunity to strengthen her store and establish her pupuseria. Her income is more stable and she has used it to make improvements to her home and provide her family with a better lifestyle.

With the intention of continuing to grow her business, she has decided on taking out a new loan to invest in oil, bread, eggs, detergent, rice, pasta etc. so that her customers will always be able to find what they need.

loans.use: to buy oil, bread, eggs, detergent, rice, pasta etc. so that her customers will always be able to find what they need.

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Charlita is a married woman with five children. She is 40 years old and five of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Charlita has a fishing business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 4 years. She requested a PHP 6,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fish nets and other fishing supplies.

In the future, Charlita would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fish nets and other fishing supplies

loans.name: Sagarara Group

texts.en:
Bernard is part of the group Sagarara and lives in Gitega. He is 34 years old and married to Francine, a farmer. Together they have three children, of whom two are students.

Bernard has been doing commerce in rice, palm oil, beans, … for five years. 

He is on his 1st Turame loan. With the KIVA loan he is obtaining, he is going to increase his capital and to purchase a large amount of rice and beans to resell, so as to earn more.

loans.use: to purchase a large amount of rice and beans to resell, so as to earn more

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase many kitchen utensils to resell, so as to earn more

loans.name: Yousra

texts.en:
Yousra is a 38-year-old married mother of four children.  She works hard to support her abroad husband in covering their children's increasing living needs.

Ten years ago Yousra started selling clothes at her house. Her husband supported her by bringing several clothing items with him from Germany and helped in developing her business and increasing her capital.

Today, Yousra is working hard to please her customers. Through her acquired loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua, she will do the needed maintenance at her house, by fixing up her clothes selling area with attractive curtains to make it a more attractive place.

She is working hard to open her own larger clothes selling shop in the future, to expand her working sector, and to diversify her products.

loans.use: To do the necessary maintenance at her home to make her selling area more attractive to customers

loans.name: Mayra Elizabeth

texts.es:
En  el sector  de la calle 26 de Septiembre  de la ciudad de Portoviejo capital manabita conocida como la Ciudad De Los reales Tamarindos, se reúnen  cada quince días los socios  del Grupo De Crédito Las Acacias. 
En este lugar vive doña Mayra, tiene 34 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene dos hijos de 18 y 4  años de edad, el mayor estudia en colegio. El marido es guardia de seguridad.
La señora Mayra es una mujer muy trabajadora que le gusta ganarse lo suyo y con sus ganancias contribuir con los gastos que demandan el hogar y la crianza de sus hijos, ella tiene un pequeño local en su casa, allí los fines de semana vende comidas rápidas como hamburguesas, hot dog, corviches, empanadas, jugos, colas, aguas, entre otras cosas que ella prepara, sus hijos y esposo le ayudan aunque ella realiza la mayor parte del trabajo, ya son casi 8 años que lleva con su negocio el cual le permite ganar lo suyo por el bien de su familia, ella agradece a la fundación Espoir y a los grupos y personas que contribuyen para que personas como ella puedan recibir un crédito y mejorar su vida.
Este crédito lo va utilizar en comprar plátano, pescado, carne, colas, aguas, frutas  y otros víveres para la preparación de los alimentos. Este es su tercer ciclo en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque los créditos le permiten salir adelante.  Sus sueños son tener un gran restaurante.
texts.en:
On 26 de Septiembre street in the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabita, known as the City of Royal Tamarinds, the members of the Grupo de Crédito Las Acacias meet every 15 days. This is where Mayra lives. She is 34 years old and lives in a domestic partnership, from which she has two children who are 18 and 4. The oldest is in high school. Her husband is a security guard.

Señora Mayra is a hard-working woman who likes to earn her own keep. With her earnings she contributes to the expenses generated by her household and bringing up her children.

She has a little store in her house where, on the weekends, she sells fast foods such as hamburgers, corviches, [a kind of fish cake made with banana] empanadas, juice, soda and water, among other things that she prepares. Her children and husband help although she does the majority of the work. It has been almost 8 years that she's had this business, which allows her to earn her own money for the good of her family. She thanks Fundación Espoir and the groups and individuals who contribute so that people like her can receive a loan and improve their lives.

She will use this loan to buy bananas, fish, meat, sodas, water, fruits and supplies to prepare food. This is her third cycle in the Credit Group, and she likes it because the loans help her to get ahead. She dreams of having a great restaurant.

loans.use: to buy bananas, fish, meat, sodas, water, fruit and other supplies.

loans.name: Gloria Monserrate

texts.es:
En  el sector conocido como 4 esquinas en la ciudad de Portoviejo se reúnen  cada quince días las socias  del Grupo De Crédito Nueva Esperanza, Portoviejo es una ciudad rodeada de vegetación y un hermoso rio que baña los campos los mismos que son propicios para los cultivos.
En este lugar vive la señorita Gloria, tiene 36 años de edad,  es madre soltera de dos hijos de 15 y 8 años de edad, ambos estudian en colegio y escuela. 
Doña Gloria es una muy buena madre y ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos y con estos poder sacar adelante a  sus hijos se dedica al comercio, ella vende ropa, zapatos por catalogo así como también perfumes, cosméticos, cremas, accesorios, entre otras cosas. Su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y por pedidos, ella sale a recorrer por su localidad dos o tres días a la semana y no tiene horarios fijos sino cuando ella puede, deja sus productos a crédito y  cobra cada 8 días, lleva más de 15 años en este negocio el cual  le permite ganarse el sustento para ella y sus hijos ya que es madre y padre a la vez.
Este crédito lo va  a emplear para comprar ropa, perfumes, cremas, bisutería entre otros productos. Lleva 3 ciclos  en el Grupo De Crédito y le gusta porque con los créditos comenzó su negocio. Sus sueños son darles lo mejor a sus hijos.
texts.en:
In the area known as "4 esquinas" (Four Corners), in the city of Portoviejo, the members of the Nueva Esperanza communal bank meet every two weeks. 

Portoviejo is a city surrounded by vegetation and a beautiful river that provides water to irrigate the fields, which are favourable for growing crops.

In this place lives Gloria. She is 36 years old and is a single mother of two children—aged 15 and 8. Both of them go to school.

Gloria is a very good mother and homemaker, who, in order to generate her own income and provide for her children, makes a living as a merchant. She sells products by catalogue such as clothes, shoes, perfumes, cosmetics, creams, and accessories, among other items. She sells door to door and upon order. She does her rounds throughout her neighbourhood two to three days a week and does them whenever she can as she doesn't have a fixed schedule. She sells her products on credit and collects payments every week. She has been running this business for over 15 years, and it has allow her to earn a living for her and her children since she is both a mother and a father to them.

She will use this loan to buy clothes, perfumes, creams, and costume jewellery, among other products.

She has been with the communal bank for three loan cycles, and she likes it because she started her business with the loans.

Her dream is to give her children the best she can.

loans.use: to buy clothes, perfumes, creams, costume jewellery, and the like.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a widowed woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be honest. 

She operates a tailoring business where she makes clothes. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in an area good for business, and her primary customers are locals. 

She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy more stock of tailoring materials. She hopes that in the future, she will prosper. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of tailoring materials.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida is a married woman with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 52 years old and has two children who are in school. She has a business buying and selling coconut wine in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase containers of coconut wine to sell.

Adelaida has been in this business for seven years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase containers of coconut wine to sell.

loans.name: Sughran

texts.en:
Sughran is 49 years old, a married woman. She is a mother of 10 children. Her husband has been doing a business of animal sales, and has been doing this for many years. Sughran fully supports and assists her husband with his work. 

Now she has requested a loan of 45,000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount to purchase more cattle for reselling in the market. 

She desires to improving her standard of living thorough all her efforts.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en:
Immaculee is aged 35 years. She is married with four children aged between 1 and 10 years. Two of them go to school. She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for the past 12 years, while her husband is a businessman. 

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy land for farming.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en:
Sumaira  is a 37-year-old married woman. She is been working in hand embroidery. She makes beautiful patterns for the people of her community. Her designs are much in demand, and she has managed to build a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her home. 

To help her to continue her operations, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR  to buy spools of thread in different colors, along with packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment; this will allow her to cater to more customers consistently. 

She is hopeful to get an increase in her income by targeting more customers. She dreams of her bright future, and desires to build her own house.

loans.use: to buy spools of thread in different colors and along with packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment.

loans.name: Griyija Muyira Group

texts.fr:
Calinie fait partie du groupe  Giriyuja Muyira et  habite à  Bujumbura. Elle a 47 ans et est mariée à venant,un enseignant. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 6 à 20 ans ,tous étudient.
 

Elle fait le commerce de  l'huile,bananzs murs,...  depuis  2 ans. 

C’est son premier   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  de  l'huile de palme mais, à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  acheter une parcelle ,construire une maison,et voir se enfants étudient.
texts.en:
Calinie is part of the group   Giriyuja Muyira and lives in Bujumbura. She is 47 years old and married to Venant, a teacher. Together, they have five children, aged 6 to 20, of whom all are students. 

Calinie has been doing commerce in oil and ripe bananas two years. 

She is on her 1st Turame loan. With the KIVA loan she is obtaining, she is going to increase her capital and to purchase palm oil and corn to resell, so as to earn more

In the coming years, she would like to purchase a parcel of land, build a house, and see her children educated.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil and corn to resell, so as to earn more

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy manure and for pruning the banana plantation.

loans.name: Shama

texts.en:
Shama is a 24-year-old, active borrower of Kiva and BRAC Pakistan. She is a mother of one daughter. Her husband is a guardian of her family and manages the household.  He has been running a spare parts business for the past 7 years. He wants to expand the size of his business, so that he can fulfill the demands of his daily customers and provide a better selling service of auto spare parts. Due to financial problems her husband is not in such position to bear these expanses.

Therefore, she has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. This loan will enable him to afford all relevant expenses in the expansion of his business, and to buy the above relevant items to fulfill his customers’ needs. For this financial assistance, Shama is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help her husband to increase his spare parts business.

loans.name: Rani

texts.en:
Rani is 49 years old, a married woman doing a business of animals’ purchase and sale for many years with the help of her husband. Her business has provided her family with a decent life. She is a mother of three children. She is very motivated to provide them a beautiful life with good education, food and clothing. 

She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She intends to utilize this loan amount to purchase more baby goats and calves to cater to more customers. 

She is hopeful that her business will generate greater revenue in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more baby goats and calves

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en:
Kalsoom is 61 years old, a vigorous, married woman. She is a mother of six children. 

She has had a business of hand embroidery for many years.  She knows the art of making beautiful embroidery patterns with beads and pearls. She is zealous about her work, and client demand is strong.  But business challenges, combined with family expenditures, frustrate her nearly every day. Her husband does not earn enough to support his family well alone. 

Kalsoom’s embroidery patterns are very popular on her street, and she is the best earning resource in her household. 

She wants to grow her business, so she requested a loan of 40,000 PKR  to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities to consistently meet the increasing demand. This will help her to gain more profits for fulfilling her dream of opening her own shop in the market to display her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities

loans.name: Asunta

texts.es:
La socia Asunta se dedica al negocio de venta de artesania,la socia vende mantas y telares, la socia por medio de este negocio quiere salir adelante y ser un empresario prospero, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de artsania.La socia solicita el crédito para comprar mantas y telares.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Asunta, the borrower works selling handicrafts. She sells blankets and looms. 

Through this business she wants to get ahead and be a successful entrepreneur. Her dream is to expand the business of selling artsania. 

She is asking for a loan to buy blankets and looms. 

She is happy about the loan and she promises to make her payments as planned.

loans.use: to buy blankets and looms.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more soap and detergent to sell

loans.name: Cholpon

texts.ru: Чолпон 49 лет, замужем, 2 детей. У нее среднее образование, в качестве дополнительного дохода с 1995 года занимается полеводством, начав этот бизнес с 15,000 сом. Благодаря упорному труду Чолпон в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется 12,0 Га земли, где она выращивает фасоль и клевер для реализации. Ежемесячный доход от бизнеса составляет 10,000 сом. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, она обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку минеральных удобрений на полеводство. Чолпон является одним из 4 участников группы "Раззак". Доходы от кредита Чолпон планирует вложить в дальнейшее развитие ее бизнеса.
texts.en: Cholpon is 49, married, and has two children. She has a secondary education and has earned additional income for her family through farming since 1995 when she started a business with 15,000 som (KGS). Thanks to her hard work she currently has a 12.0 hectare plot of land where she grows beans and clover to sell. Her monthly income from her business is 10,000 som (KGS). In order to expand her business in the future, she applied for a loan of 100,000 som (KGS) with Bai-Tushum Bank to buy fertilizers for growing crops. Cholpon is one of four members of the "Razzak" group. She plans to use her profits to continue investing in her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers to grow eco-friendly products

loans.name: Rhina Esmeralda

texts.es:
Rhina, vende carne y algunos embutidos de res, actividad que practica desde hace más de 15 años, tiene un horario de 6:00 a.m. a 4:00 p.m., lo heredó de su familia, ella adquiere las reses y paga a una persona que la destace, luego vende sus derivados, vive con su madre y un hijo, está soltera, no cuenta con apoyo económico del extranjero.
Necesita de un financiamiento para comprar reses que destazara para surtir la venta de carne, aumentara su mercadería y su negocio mantendrá su continuidad, Rhina espera que al realizar la inversión sus ingresos incrementen y mantenga la fidelidad de sus clientes.
 Sueña con tener un local propio, disminuir su nivel de endeudamiento y cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia.
texts.en:
Rhina sells meat and some beef sausages, something which she has done for over 15 years. Her timetable is from 6:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. She inherited the business from her family. She buys the cattle and pays someone to slaughter them, and then sells the products that she gets from them. She lives with her mother and a child and is single. She does not receive external economic support. 

She needs a loan to buy cattle to butcher to create stock for her meat sales. This will increase her merchandise and allow her business to continue. Rhina hopes that the investment will increase her profits and maintain the loyalty of her customers. 
 
She dreams of having her own place, reducing her level of debt and covering the basic necessities of her family.

loans.use: to buy cattle to butcher to create stock for her meat sales. This will increase her merchandise and allow her business to continue

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea, 62, is an agricultural entrepreneur from Iboi, in the Kapsowar region of Kenya. This father has been actively doing this work for fifteen good years. Andrea makes a decent income selling milk, eggs, maize and other crops that he produces, at the local market. He is also engaged in other personal businesses to make additional income. 

Poultry farming has worked out particularly well for Andrea, mainly because of the growing demand for chicken products and by-products. He also attributes his success to the passion and vision he has for the business. He enjoys feeding his dairy cow and harvesting his crops. The biggest risks his business faces are outbreaks of disease and market uncertainties. 

Andrea is seeking a loan to purchase more poultry. With this money, he will expand his business by buying a brood of hens, which will lay more eggs to sell. Andrea has nurtured a saving culture. He will use the money from this investment to build his savings account and provide his family with a balanced diet and better living conditions.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Julienne

texts.en:
Julienne is aged 31 years. She is married with five children aged between 1 and 10 years.  Three of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 11 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Anatori

texts.en:
Anatori is 34 years old and lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is a married, hard-working man with four children.

He used the previous loan to buy more clothes to sell. Anatori started his business to increase his income. He wants to expand his business, despite the challenges of inadequate capital and high taxes paid for the business operation. 

Anatori will use the loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Muhamedi

texts.en: Muhamedi is a 47-year-old man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He deals in mechanics and at the same time is a farmer. He faces challenges of limited capital, that hinder progress in his business. Besides that, he has hopes of expanding his business to new areas. He has asked for a loan to buy spare parts for vehicles and motorcycles to sell.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for vehicles and motorcycles for resale.

loans.name: Dalia Marisol

texts.es:
Dalia, está necesitando de un nuevo crédito para comprar harina, quesillo, aceite, repollos, aderezos, bebidas, etc., y una mesa con sillas para elaborar las pupusas y brindar mayor comodidad a sus clientes.
Los créditos le dan los recursos económicos a Dalia para tener a su disposición la materia prima para que su negocio se mantenga con vida y así tener los ingresos necesarios para apoyar a sus hijos a que se superen académicamente.
texts.en:
Dalia needs a new loan in order to buy flour, quesillo [soft cheese], oil, cabbages, and seasonings, to make pupusas [corn flour stuffed with cheese, refried beans, or meat], drinks, etc., and a table with chairs, to offer greater convenience to her clients. 

The loans offer Dalia financial resources in order to have raw materials on hand for her business to keep her business alive and thus have the necessary income to support her children so they can achieve academically.

loans.use: to buy flour, quesillo, oil, cabbages, and seasonings to make pupusas, drinks, etc., and a table with chairs to offer greater convenience to her customers.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph lives in Hoima, Uganda. He deals in produce, mainly buying and selling of maize, beans, and rice among other items, supplemented by income from farming. He dreams of expanding and developing his business, however, price fluctuations pose a threat to his business sustainability. He will use the loan facility to buy more maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy more maize to sell.

loans.name: Suriya

texts.en:
Suriya is a 49-year-old woman and mother of three children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. 

Her husband has been running a milk shop for the past 14 years. He is solely responsible for feeding the entire family and managing the household. Suriya's husband needs to purchase milk to resell so that he can increase the size of business, improve his sales growth and earn maximum profit. Due to an unfavorable financial position, her husband is not in a position to purchase milk for his business. Therefore, Suriya has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner, BRAC Pakistan, in order to help her husband to purchase the milk for his business.
 
She is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase milk for her husband's milk shop.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem  is 46 years old; she is a married woman.  She deals in a business selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, brings them up, and then sells them out in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. 

Naseem needs to improve her business to cover her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 45,000  to purchase more animals to grow her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to grow her sales.

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
Sajida  is 31 years old, a vigorous married woman. She has had a business of hand-embroidery for many years.  She knows the art of making beautiful embroidery patterns with beads and pearls. She is zealous about her work, and client demand is strong, but business challenges, combined with family expenditures, frustrate her nearly every day. Her husband does not earn enough to support his family well alone. 

Sajida’s embroidery patterns are very popular on her street and she is the best earning resource in her household. She is a mother of one child. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of 40,000 PKR,  to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand time after time so as to earn more profit for fulfilling her dream of opening her own shop in the market to display her work.

loans.use: to buy raw materials such as thread, sequins and pearls in large quantities to meet the increasing demand time after time.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow to enable her to add more stock to her retail shop and meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Alice works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable-vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling spices.  Alice is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy more vegetables to sell in her food stall.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Alice has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine is aged 33 years. She is married with two children, aged 1 and 4 years. They do not yet go to school. She is a farmer, and she has been growing maize for the past 12 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Pridon

texts.en: Pridon is 53 years old. He lives in Zestaponi district with his wife. Pridon is involved in agricultural activities. He cultivates  a 0.7 hectare family-owned farm and has three cows and several hens. Pridon decided to expand his farming and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables him to get a loan of 1,800 GEL. With the received credit he will purchase sheep. He will be able to expand farming and this will increase his income, as he will sell more milk and also wool.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and expand farming

loans.name: Jubwego Foundation Women Group (Kiracha)

texts.en:
The person holding a passbook for Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the photo is John. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa to benefit from the training, especially financial management and record-keeping.

He is 26 years old and practices vegetable farming where he grows potatoes, cabbages, and kale. He is borrowing from Kiva to buy high quality certified seeds that will increase production of the vegetables hence more yield and more income.

John is happy about Kiva and its lenders and hopes to continue taking more loans to boost his vegetable farming business.

loans.use: To buy high quality certified seeds to increase production of potatoes, cabbages, and kale, hence more income.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase detergents to sell so that she can educate her children and repay her loan

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 50 years old. He has six children. He has had a farming business for 14 years. He will be using the loan to purchase farm inputs and hopes this will help him produce more food. 


His hopes and dreams for the future are to have enough food to supply to the whole community with food, educate his children and buy more cows.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow so that he can start supplying milk to customers and thereby earn more income.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia is 51 years old.

Amelia has a buying and selling of rice business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 8,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more sacks of rice to sell.

Amelia has been in this business for four years. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Alexis

texts.en:
Alexis is 37 years old. He is married with four children aged between 2 and 9 years; three of them go to school. He is a farmer, and he has been growing maize for the past nine years, while his wife is a businesswoman. With the loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Eustaqiua

texts.en:
Eustaqiua is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Eustaqiua is 60 years old and has five children who are in school.

Eustaqiua has a abaca weaving business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 9000 loan amount through NWTF to buy abaca fiber for her business.

Eustaqiua has been in this business for 20 years. In the futur she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy abaca fiber for her business

loans.name: Cindy

texts.en:
Cindy is 20 years old and has four children, one in school.

Cindy is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and other farm supplies to raise her livestock.

She has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed two times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, she would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and other farm supplies to raise her livestock

loans.name: Nodar

texts.en:
Nodar is 56 years old and a married man. He lives with his wife in Kvareli district. Nodar is a physical worker and gets a small monthly income which is the only source of income for his family. 

Nodar decided to start his own business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo enables him to get a loan of 1500 Gel. With the received credit he will cultivate family-owned agricultural land and will grow watermelon there. The Start Up loan will be a great support for his family and he will be able to generate his own income and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to cultivate his agricultural land and grow watermelon

loans.name: Bazirio

texts.en:
Bazirio is a 54-year-old, hardworking, married man. He has five children aged 18, 14, 8, 6 and 2 years. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He deals in livestock rearing alongside farming, where he earns extra income. He hopes to expand his cattle farm and increase the number of cows at the farm, though he faces a challenge of dry seasons that lead to a lack of pasture and water.

He is requesting a loan to buy more calves to add to his farm.

loans.use: to buy more calves to add to his farm.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is 33 years old. He is married with three children aged between 1 and 8 years. One of them goes to school. He is a farmer and he has been growing maize for the past 10 years, while his wife is a businesswoman. 

With this loan from Kiva, he would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Asaph

texts.en:
Asaph is a 43 year old hard-working married man. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He has four children, ages 18, 16, 10, and 4 years. He deals in livestock rearing and milk selling where he earns a living and pays school fees for his children. He has a vision of specializing in animal rearing but he faces a challenge of accidents when transporting animals to markets.

Asaph is requesting a loan to buy more cows for fattening on his farm.

loans.use: to buy more cows for fattening on his farm.

loans.name: Luan

texts.en:
Luan is 33 and has been photographed with his wife, Mirela, and their 3-year-old, who is the youngest of the two children. The other child is 7 years old. Mirela is very ill and immediate surgery has been scheduled for her. “I am afraid that I will not come out of that surgery and this has upset me the most. My kids are very young and they need me. During the day I try to not cry in front of the kids, but as soon as I find myself alone, I cannot stop my tears,” said Mirela wiping away her tears.
While Luan or ‘tiger’ in English has been working in construction, agriculture/livestock has been their focus since they got married. They plant corn and also have pigs and raise pigs for sale. They sell the corn or use it to feed the pigs.

loans.use: to pay for his wife's surgery that has been scheduled

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow to provide more income from the milk.

loans.name: Ernestine

texts.en:
Ernestine is 35 years old. She is married with two children, who are two and four years old and do not yet go to school. She is a farmer and has been growing maize for the past 13 years. Her husband is a businessman.

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a motorcycle.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Stephanie

texts.en:
Stephanie is aged 45 years. She is married with eight children aged between 4 and 25 years. Six of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 22 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be use to buy a piece of land.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Venantie

texts.en:
Venantie is 27 years old. She is married with 4 children, aged 1 to 9 years.  Two of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 10 years. While her husband is a business man. With the loan from Kiva, she would to pay the workers who harvested her maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvest her maize.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 36 years old. She is married with 3 children aged between 5 and 15 years.  They all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 17 years. Her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Margarithe

texts.en:
Margarithe is 38 years old. She is married with four children aged between 2 and 14 years, three of whom go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 21 years. Her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under-served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Fernando Arturo

texts.es:
Fernando, es joven emprendedor de 18 años de edad, vive con sus padres de 50 y 49 años de edad, dos hermanos de 23 y 9 años de edad, su negocio consiste en dar el servicio de cortes de cabello y barba, actividad que aprendió con la ayuda de un amigo y desarrolla como negocio propia desde hace dos años, trabaja sin un horario definido en su residencia y también lo hace a domicilio cuando sus clientes lo solicitan.
El crédito lo invertirá en una silla, un espejo, una máquina para cortar pelo, tijeras, talco y gel, le ayudara a tener un negocio debidamente equipado y a ofrecer un mejor servicio a sus clientes, espera que su clientela aumente así como también sus ingresos para cubrir sus compromisos.
Los sueños de Fernando son estudiar en la universidad la carrera de Licenciatura en el idioma inglés, tomar cursos para perfeccionar sus conocimientos en cortes de cabello y ser un apoyo económico para sus padres.
texts.en:
Fernando is an enterprising young man, 18 years old. He lives with his parents, ages 50 and 49, two siblings, ages 23 and 9, and his business is providing haircuts and beard trims, work that he learned with the help of a friend, and he has done as his own business for two years.  He works without a set schedule in his house and also makes house calls when the customers ask for them.

The loan will be invested in a chair, a mirror, hair clippers, scissors, talcum powder, and gel; it will help him have a properly equipped business and offer better service to his customers. He hopes that his customers will increase and also his income, to cover his commitments.

Fernando's dream is to study at the university to get a degree in English, take courses to perfect his knowledge of haircuts, and be an economic support for his parents.

loans.use: to purchase a seat, a mirror, hair clippers, scissors, talcum powder and gel; it will help him have a properly equipped business.

loans.name: Bruhan

texts.en:
Bruhan is a 34-year-old, hardworking, married man with two children, aged 4 and 2 years. He lives in Kamwenge, Uganda. He trades in produce and also deals in motorcycle transport (boda boda) to earn additional income. He hopes to expand and become a modern farmer and to educate his children. He says price fluctuations have greatly affected his business. 

Bruhan is requesting a loan to buy more produce, especially bags of maize, coffee and beans, to sell.

loans.use: to buy more produce, especially bags of maize, coffee and beans to sell.

loans.name: Maria Liduvina

texts.es:
María, de 48 años de edad, estudio profesorado, está casada y su esposo es empleado público, tienen cuatro hijos y todos estudian y viven con ella.

María, trabaja como profesora desde hace 22 años, se dedico a estudiar para ser maestra, pues siempre deseó trabajar con niños y educarlos.- María, quiere poner un negocio de venta de hielo, porque donde vive nadie vende y muchas veces tienen que ir lejos a comprar; su lugar de trabajo está a media hora desde su casa, viaja en autobús, la venta de hielo será desde las 8:00 a.m. hasta las 6:00 p.m. 

María, necesita el crédito para comprar una refrigeradora, para la venta de hielo.- El préstamo le ayudará tanto a ella como a las personas que buscan este producto.

Su sueños son, tener la refrigeradora para la venta de hielo y para poder guardar sus alimentos y que no se le arruinen.
texts.en:
María, 48 years old, studied to be a teacher, is married, and her husband is a public employee. They have four children and all of them are students and live with her.

María has worked as a teacher for 22 years. She studied to be a teacher because she always wanted to work with children and educate them. María wants to open a business selling ice because where she lives, no one sells it and many times they need to go far to buy it. Her workplace is a half-hour from her house, she goes by bus. She would sell ice from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.

María needs the loan to purchase a refrigerator to sell ice. The loan will help her as well as the people looking for this product. 

Her dreams are to have the refrigerator to sell ice and to be able to keep her food so it doesn't go bad.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator to sell ice.

loans.name: David's Group

texts.en:
David is 47 years old and has five children. He is a group leader and is representing his group formed by 12 farmers in Webuye District, Kenya. 

David has been farming with One Acre Fund for years now, having joined the program for the first time in 2010. This decision was largely a result of his desire to earn enough to feed his family and, although he described his last harvest as very good, he believes he could have a better one this year by continuing to work alongside One Acre Fund. David also decided to purchase a solar light as part of his loan, which he is very excited about, as it will allow him to reduce their consumption of paraffin fuel and therefore save more money.

Obtaining this loan means that David's Group will be able to receive a total of eight solar lights, as well as farming inputs to plant a total of 7 acres.

loans.use: to purchase a solar light and gain access to cost-efficient hybrid seeds and fertilizer for maize cultivation.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cosmetics and sell them to customers door-to-door.

loans.name: Mmasi's Group

texts.en:
Mmasi, featured in the above picture, is representing her farming group formed by 12 farmers in Webuye District, Kenya. She is 53 years old and a married mother of 6 children, often described as a very hard-working individual. 

Although Mmasi has been a farmer for 20 years, she is new to One Acre Fund and decided to join this year because she really wanted to have access to quality training and acquire new farming methods. Even though she is new to the program, Mmasi wanted to represent her group because she wanted to help more farmers. With the profits earned from this season’s harvest, Mmasi hopes to be able to send her children to school.

With this loan, the group will receive farming inputs to plant a total of 5.25 acres of land. They will also receive a total of 8 solar lights, as, even though Mmasi decided not to, some of the farmers in the group will be purchasing a solar light as part of their loan package.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize

loans.name: Fidaa

texts.en: Fidaa is a 44-year-old married Lebanese woman living with her husband and four children. She has been working at her house since 2006 in tailoring to help her family meet the needs of life. She is well-known in her region by her good reputation. To better develop her work, Fidaa is requesting a second loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. She will be utilizing the loan to buy a sewing machine for her business with the aim of increasing her income and improving her work. This will allow her to offer a greater variety of products and properly serve her customers.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine for her business

loans.name: Cristina

texts.es:
La socia Cristiana  se dedica al negocio de venta de artesania,la socia vende mantas y telares, la socia por medio de este negocio quiere salir adelante y ser un empresario prospero, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de artsania.La socia solicita el crédito para comprar mantas y telares.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Cristiana works in a business selling crafts. She sells blankets and woven products. Through this work, she wants to get ahead and be a prosperous businesswoman. Her dream is to expand her business selling crafts. She asks for the loan to purchase blankets and woven products.

She is happy for the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to purchase blankets and woven products.

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Erma works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from buying and selling spices. Erma is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall for her vegetable vending business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Erma has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream:  to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty lives in Hoima, Uganda. She is a hard working 35-year-old married woman charged with the responsibility of taking care of four children. She desires to raise and educate her children. All of them attend school in Hoima, Uganda.

She owns a boutique that sells mainly sportswear, supplementing her income with farming. Protecting her business from bad debtors is a challenge that she faces. She is seeking credit to buy more sportswear to sell.

loans.use: to buy more sportswear to sell.

loans.name: Octavia

texts.en: Octavia used her previous loan to buy farm inputs like fertilizers. She deals in farming as her main source of income alongside selling local brew known as tonto and waragi. She started this business to earn a living and improve her standard of living. She faces the challenges of competition, seasonal customers and weather changes that stop customers from turning up, but has hopes that she will have a waragi factory in her village. She is requesting a loan to buy more farm inputs like fertilizers and manure to improve her banana plantation.

loans.use: to buy more farm inputs like fertilizers and manure to improve her banana plantation.

loans.name: Reinaldo Fredy

texts.es:
Reinaldo, es propietario de un taller de reparación y venta de llantas para automóvil y motocicletas, tiene 55 años de edad, vive con su compañera de vida y una hija con edades de 24 y 7 años respectivamente, tiene 6 años de haber hecho la apertura de su negocio y lo atiende a tiempo completo.
Utilizará el financiamiento para comprar llantas para automóvil y motocicletas, surtirá su inventario para atender las necesidades de sus clientes, espera poder mantener su negocio con vida para generar los ingresos necesarios con los que podrá disminuir las necesidades familiares.
Reinaldo se esfuerza por trabajar día con día para lograr el sueño de darle a su familia un mejor futuro y contar con un negocio más rentable.
texts.en:
Reinaldo is 55 years old and lives with his 24-year-old wife and their six-year-old daughter. He has for the past six years run a shop selling and repairing automobile and motorcycle tires, and works there full-time. 

Reinaldo will use the funds from this loan to purchase automobile and motorcycle tires, expanding his inventory so he can meet the needs of his customers. He hopes that he can keep running his business and earn enough income to reduce his family's needs. He strives each day to ensure that his business will be more profitable, and allow him to fulfill his dream of providing his family a better future.

loans.use: to purchase automobile and motorcycle tires so he can expand his inventory and meet the needs of his customers.

loans.name: Marta Gloria

texts.es:
Marta, está satisfecha por haber obtenido grandes beneficios de la inversión anterior en su venta de mariscos y semilla de marañón, manifiesta que su negocio logro cubrir las demandas de sus clientes y con las ganancias ha mejorado la infraestructura de su nuevo hogar, ella y su familia han cambiado de domicilio para tener una vida más confortable.
Está solicitando un crédito nuevo para comprar semilla de marañón y seguir trabajando, el resto de capital le servirá para hacer otras reparaciones en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Marta is satisfied for having gotten great benefit from the previous investment in her sales of shellfish and cashews. She says that her business managed to meet her customers' demand and with the earnings, she has improved the infrastructure of her new home. She and her family have moved to a new house to have a more comfortable life.

She is asking for another loan to purchase cashews and continue working. The rest of the capital will be used to do other repairs on her house.

loans.use: to purchase cashews and continue working, the rest of the capital will be used to do other repairs on her house.

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es:
María, requiere un nuevo crédito para comprar maíz, dulces, pan, especias, jabón, jugos, etc., para mantener surtido su negocio y contar con la satisfacción de sus clientes.
El financiamiento anterior le ha facilitado ofrecer variedad de productos en su negocio, con ello ha tenido los ingresos que necesita para subsistir y hasta la fecha no representa ningún problema para mantenerse trabajando.
texts.en:
María needs another loan to purchase corn, sweets, bread, spices, soap, juices, etc. to keep her business stocked and have customer satisfaction.
